awd_titl_txt: Unifying Principles for the Design and Manufacture of Chemically-Patterned Polymeric Membranes
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to their ability to control molecular transport, membranes are essential components of modern separations (e.g., water treatment) and sensing (e.g., glucose monitoring) processes. As their application has advanced, a need for more selective membranes has emerged. In this regard, engineered systems that take inspiration from biological membranes provide one route toward realizing more selective membranes. To bring this new paradigm to fruition, processes for patterning the surface chemistry of membranes in a manner that is consistent with proven manufacturing methods are needed. This award leverages recent advances in the fields of nanostructured polymers, membrane manufacturing, and ink-jet printing to address fundamental scientific issues related to the production of charge-patterned mosaic membranes. The fundamental knowledge to be gained has broad implications for manufacturing of multifunctional membranes that address critical challenges needed to ensure the well-being and prosperity of the American people. For example, by changing the formulation of the reactive inks, unique functions are possible leading to the development of therapeutic medicine or chemical and biological threat detectors. This project is multidisciplinary and involves polymer chemistry, transport phenomena, and nanostructured materials. It helps revolutionize the manufacturing landscape of the U.S. by training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists and engineers.

Charge-patterned mosaic membranes consist of discrete positively-charged and negatively-charged domains that traverse the membrane thickness. They are used to initiate this line of inquiry because their ability to transport salts selectively emerges directly from their patterned chemistry. Despite their potential utility in separations and sensing applications, the selective transport mechanisms of these membranes are poorly understood. This critical knowledge gap is a direct result of challenges related to manufacturing chemically-patterned membranes. In particular, morphological changes induced during the harsh chemical treatments required to introduce charged functionality have hampered prior efforts to generate this class of membranes. Here, this engineering opportunity is met by integrating nanostructured copolymer substrates that are amenable to functionalization using 'click' reactions with ink-jet printer-mediated deposition of reactive inks. This research enables the systematic design and manufacture of charge-patterned membranes. It studies the fabrication of self-assembled copolymer membrane substrates that are molecularly-engineered to enable chemical-patterning using ink-jet printing. It evaluates the performance of charge-patterned membranes in model chemical separations to correlate membrane performance with pattern design and composition. The project advances the use of additive manufacturing within the field of membrane science and delivers a versatile membrane technology that offers improved selectivity in traditional and emerging applications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF NOTRE DAME DU LAC

por.por_cntn:
Membranes are essential components of modern separations (e.g., water treatment) and sensing (e.g., glucose monitoring) processes. As their application continues to expand, a need for more selective membranes, which are better able to distinguish between molecules of varying size, charge, and chemistry, has emerged. Engineered systems that draw inspiration from biological membranes provide one route toward producing such membranes. At the nanoscale, biological membranes are made up of chemically-distinct domains that work synergistically to control the transport of chemical species with exceptional precision. In contrast, current engineered membranes are typically based on a single material chemistry. Therefore, processes for manufacturing multifunctional, chemically-patterned membranes are needed to enable the exploration of next-generation membranes inspired by nature.

This multidisciplinary project aimed to address key technical opportunities related to the production of charge-patterned mosaic membranes. Namely, by formulating reactive inks and printing them onto tailor-made copolymer substrates, the relationships between the manufacturing process, the substrate nanostructure, and the selective transport properties of charge-patterned membranes were examined. Charge mosaic membranes were identified as the initial target because their ability to transport electrolytes (i.e., dissolved salts) selectively arises directly from their charge-patterned surface. Moreover, the selective transport of dissolved salts is critical to many technologies that are necessary to meet the growing demand for water and energy; to support the development of therapeutic medicine; and to detect chemical and biological threats. While the proposed research is focused on charge-patterned membranes, the fundamental knowledge to be gained has broad implications for manufacturing multifunctional membranes that address other critical challenges needed to ensure the well-being and prosperity of the American people.

Through the course of this award, the project made substantial progress integrating nanostructured membrane substrates with additive manufacturing. To start, the molecular design and synthesis of a copolymer that could be transformed into nanostructured substrates amenable to chemical-modification via the ink-jet printing of click chemistry-based reactive inks was standardized. It was shown that the formulation of the reactive ink was crucial to ensuring control over the functionalization process. Notably, while initial efforts to formulate the reactive inks were pursued using an Edisonian approach, execution of this proposal allowed for a computational-experimental framework that integrated physics-informed modeling and data science to be established. Using this framework, the reactive ink formulation was optimized in a rational manner to increase the reaction rate between the ink and the nanostructured membrane substate. These conditions enabled the design of the printing protocol to provide fine control over the charge-patterned membrane surfaces. These accomplishments underscore the practical versatility of the self-assembled copolymer and reactive inks system, positioning it as a robust platform technology for application in selective membrane processes.

Empowered by the results generated regarding the membrane manufacturing and functionalization processes, clear relationships between membrane characteristics (e.g., surface charge, pattern geometry) and the transport properties of charge mosaic membranes were elucidated. For example, by systematically varying the geometry and size of the charge pattern, the interactions between distinct domains that promote salt transport were revealed. Membrane performance scaled directly with the interfacial packing density, which quantified the fraction of the membrane surface covered by junctions between oppositely charged domains, for membranes patterned with equal areal coverages of positively charged and negatively charged domains. In experiments with symmetric electrolytes (e.g., KCl and MgSO4) salt flux increased with the value of the interfacial packing density. For asymmetric electrolytes (i.e., K2SO4 and MgCl2), however, the interfacial packing density did not affect the salt flux significantly. These findings demonstrate the promise of accessing transport mechanisms, which could find utility for the recovery of resources from wastewaters and the recycling of critical minerals from electronic waste, through chemical patterning of membranes. As such, this research program creates opportunities to make progress toward elucidating the critical structure-processing-property relationships for membranes that offer improved selectivity.

In addition to the outcomes associated with laboratory work and analysis, this project was instrumental in advancing training and educational programs. Three graduate students and one postdoctoral researcher were trained through the execution of this award. During this award, these researchers were trained on experimental techniques that improved their ink-jet printing, membrane manufacturing, transport phenomena, and data science knowledge to a significant degree. In addition to the training of graduate researchers, seven undergraduate researchers and one high school researcher participated in the project. The opportunity to supplement their classroom-based training with meaningful experimentation provided an engaging hands-on component to their training as scientists and engineers. Through these efforts, it is our sincere hope that this work has significantly improved the technology and training landscape of the United States.

 


Last Modified: 03/27/2024
Modified by: William A Phillip

Image
  • Schematics of stripe-patterned (ST- CMM), cubically-patterned (CU-CMM), and hexagonally-patterned (HE-CMM) charge-patterned mosaic membranes. The interfacial junctions between oppositely-charged domains are highlighted in yellow. Fluorescent micrographs of charge-patterned mosaic membranes.
    Feng Gao
    Copyrighted
    William A Phillip
    Charge-patterned mosaic membranes with varied interfacial packing densities
